  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

More than half (53%) of Australians have regretted a purchase or had a negative experience during Black Friday sales, a Choice survey has found.

The consumer advocate warned shoppers to be wary of ‚Äúunmissable‚Äù deals and other strategies that create a false sense of urgency, with businesses already rolling out early discounts before Black Friday sales officially start on 28 November.

Misleading ‚Äústore-wide‚Äù or ‚Äúsite-wide‚Äù claims, when sales actually involve exclusions.

Fine print or disclaimers that seek to limit headline claims about the sale, including member-only deals or excluding a range of products.

Deceptive ‚Äúup to X% off‚Äù offers, with the ‚Äúup to‚Äù text almost illegible and few products at maximum discount.

Misleading ‚Äúwas/now‚Äù or ‚Äústrikethrough‚Äù pricing.

False urgency through inaccurate countdown timers and phrases like ‚Äúthree days only‚Äù that don‚Äôt align with the true duration of the sale.

items.title: ‚ÄòStranded‚Äô: Palestinians who were in Israel on 7 October 2023 are suspended between exile and war
items.content_html:
Unable to reunite with their families in Gaza due to the closed border, Palestinian workers have spent two years in a refugee camp at Nablus stadium

Inside a dim locker room at the Nablus municipal stadium, in the occupied West Bank, the television rarely goes dark, streaming day and night the relentless news from Gaza. Gathered in front of it are a group of men from Khan Younis. For more than two years, they have lived in this stadium converted into a refugee camp, their lives suspended between exile and the war they watched on a screen.

They are mostly construction workers who were in Israel on the morning of 7 October 2023 when Hamas launched its attack. As Israel rounded up Palestinians from Gaza, they fled to the West Bank, where they remain ‚Äì cut off from wives and children living in makeshift tents inside the strip. With very few exceptions, civilians are not currently allowed in or out of Gaza.

items.title: China has brought millions out of poverty. The US has not ‚Äì by choice
items.content_html:
Despite the US‚Äôs economic success, income inequality remains breathtaking. But this is no glitch ‚Äì it‚Äôs the system

The Chinese did rather well in the age of globalization. In 1990, 943 million people there lived on less than $3 a day measured in 2021 dollars ‚Äì 83% of the population, according to the World Bank. By 2019, the number was brought down to zero. Unfortunately, the United States was not as successful. More than 4 million Americans ‚Äì 1.25% of the population ‚Äì must make ends meet with less than $3 a day, more than three times as many as 35 years ago.

The data is not super consistent with the narrative of the US‚Äôs inexorable success. Sure, American productivity has zoomed ahead of that of its European peers. Only a handful of countries manage to produce more stuff per hour of work. And artificial intelligence now promises to put the United States that much further ahead.

items.title: Trump, war, absent media: five threats to climate progress that dogged Cop30
items.content_html:
Did the talks succeed or fail? The verdict must take account of the geopolitical minefield they took place in

Cop30 in Bel√©m wrapped up on Saturday night more than 24 hours later than planned, and with an Amazonian rainstorm thundering down on the conference centre. The UN structure just about held, as it has done these past three weeks despite fire, savage tropical heat and blistering political attacks on the multilateral system of global environmental governance.

Dozens of agreements were gavelled through on the final day, as the most collective form of humanity worked to resolve the most complex and dangerous challenge that our species has ever faced. It was chaotic. The process very nearly collapsed and had to be rescued by last-ditch talks that went on into the early morning. Veteran observers told me the Paris agreement was on life-support.
